results.query: Compare food and beverages versus fuel and light inflation in Bihar for 2023
results.response_text:
Here‚Äôs a clear comparison of Food & Beverages vs Fuel & Light inflation in Bihar during 2023, based on CPI (2012=100), Combined sector data from MoSPI.

üìä Big Picture (2023)
Category	Inflation Trend in 2023	Key Takeaway
Food & Beverages	High and persistent (mostly 7%‚Äì10%, peaking above 10% mid-year)	Main driver of retail inflation in Bihar
Fuel & Light	Low to negative (roughly ‚Äì3% to +3%)	Provided inflation relief, often in deflation
üçö Food & Beverages Inflation ‚Äì Bihar, 2023

Consistently elevated throughout the year

Monthly inflation (overall group):

Early 2023: ~7%

Mid-2023 peak (July): ~10.2%

End-2023 (Dec): 8.2%

Major contributors:

Vegetables: often 20‚Äì30%+ inflation

Spices: around 20‚Äì25%

Cereals: frequently 10‚Äì17%

Oils & fats showed negative inflation, but not enough to offset food pressure overall.

üìå Interpretation: Food prices were the dominant source of inflation stress for households in Bihar in 2023.

üî• Fuel & Light Inflation ‚Äì Bihar, 2023

Muted and mostly negative

Monthly inflation (overall group):

Negative for most of the year (‚Äì3% to ‚Äì1%)

Brief mild positives mid-year (max ~3.5% in May)

December 2023: ‚Äì3.4%

üìå Interpretation: Fuel and electricity prices were stable or falling, helping cushion overall CPI inflation.

üßæ Direct Comparison (What it Means)

Food inflation was structurally high and volatile

Fuel inflation was subdued and often deflationary

For Bihar in 2023:

Rising food costs eroded real purchasing power

Stable fuel prices prevented inflation from being even worse

üîë Bottom Line

In 2023, Bihar‚Äôs inflation story was overwhelmingly about food‚Äînot fuel.
Households felt the pinch at the grocery basket, while fuel and light acted as a stabilizer rather than a pressure point.

If you want, I can also:

Compare Bihar with All-India averages

Break this into Rural vs Urban

Or turn it into a ready-to-use exam answer or chart

results.query: Which is higher in urban Maharashtra: housing or transport and communication price index in December 2024?
results.response_text:
In urban Maharashtra (December 2024), housing was pricier than transport & communication.

Here are the CPI (2012=100) figures:

Housing: 178.8

Transport & Communication: 167.3

So, housing had the higher price index in December 2024.

results.query: Give me general index, cereals, and vegetables indices for rural Tamil Nadu in June 2022
results.response_text:
Here are the Consumer Price Index (CPI, base 2012=100) figures you asked for ‚Äî Rural Tamil Nadu, June 2022, straight from the MoSPI CPI dataset:

üìä CPI Indices (Rural Tamil Nadu, June 2022)

General Index (Overall): 177.9

Cereals and Products: 146.2

Vegetables: 179.5

For a bit of context (optional but useful):

Rural inflation in June 2022 was 5.33% overall.

Vegetables were especially hot that month, with 13.68% inflation, which explains the high index.

Cereals were comparatively stable at 0.62% inflation.

If you want these compared with urban Tamil Nadu, All-India, or across multiple months, I can line that up neatly.

results.query: Compare food and beverages versus pan and tobacco for all India in 2020
results.response_text:
Here‚Äôs a clear All-India comparison of Food & Beverages vs Pan, Tobacco & Intoxicants in 2020, based on CPI (2012=100), Combined sector, from MoSPI data.

Big picture (2020 average trend)
Category	Price level & trend	Inflation behaviour
Food & Beverages	Moderate but volatile	Started very high, cooled mid-year, rose again
Pan, Tobacco & Intoxicants	Consistently high	Steady double-digit inflation for most of the year
Food & Beverages (All-India, Combined)

Overall CPI index

Jan 2020: 153.5

Dec 2020: 161.0

Inflation pattern

Very high in Jan‚ÄìFeb (11‚Äì9%) driven by vegetables

Fell during Apr‚ÄìMay (COVID supply disruptions, data adjustments)

Picked up again in Oct‚ÄìDec (~9‚Äì4%)

Key drivers

Vegetables: extremely volatile (up to 50% inflation in Jan)

Pulses, oils & fats, meat & fish: sustained high inflation

Cereals and sugar: relatively stable

Takeaway: Food inflation in 2020 was uneven and shock-driven, mainly by vegetables and protein items.

Pan, Tobacco & Intoxicants (All-India, Combined)

Overall CPI index

Jan 2020: 169.2

Dec 2020: 186.5

Inflation pattern

Early 2020: ~4%

From mid-2020 onward: 10‚Äì11% consistently

Key reason

High and rising taxation (GST + excise) and administered pricing

Much less affected by seasonal supply shocks

Takeaway: This group showed stable but persistently high inflation, largely policy-driven rather than market-driven.

Direct comparison (2020)

Price level:
Pan & Tobacco prices were consistently higher than Food & Beverages throughout 2020.

Stability:
Pan & Tobacco inflation was more stable, while Food inflation was highly volatile.

Inflation pressure:

Food: driven by supply shocks

Pan & Tobacco: driven by taxes and regulation

Bottom line

In 2020, Food & Beverages affected household budgets through volatility, while Pan, Tobacco & Intoxicants exerted a steady, predictable inflationary pressure.

If you want, I can also:

Compute annual average inflation for both

Compare rural vs urban

Or show how 2020 compares with 2019 or 2021

results.query: What is the difference between health and education price index in urban Karnataka in January 2021?
results.response_text:
Here‚Äôs the breakdown from the official MoSPI CPI data for Urban Karnataka, January 2021 (base year 2012 = 100):

Health price index: 163.4

Education price index: 162.6

‚úÖ Difference

Health ‚àí Education = 163.4 ‚àí 162.6 = 0.8 index points

So, in January 2021, health prices were higher than education prices by 0.8 points in urban Karnataka.

results.query: Show me meat and fish, eggs, milk products, and oils for Gujarat in 2024
results.response_text:
Here‚Äôs what the MoSPI CPI (Consumer Price Index, base 2012) shows for 2024 for the categories you asked about ‚Äî meat & fish, eggs, milk products, and oils & fats.

‚ö†Ô∏è Important note upfront
At the item level, CPI data is published at All-India level, not state-wise. Gujarat-specific CPI is available only at higher group levels, not for individual items like eggs or milk.
So the numbers below are All-India CPI item indices, which are commonly used as a proxy when state-level item data isn‚Äôt available.

ü•© Meat & Fish (2024, CPI Index)

Goat meat (mutton): ~242 ‚Üí 251
Inflation mostly 3‚Äì4% through the year

Chicken: Highly volatile

Jan: ~205

Jul peak: ~236

Dec: ~217

Fish & prawn: ~201 ‚Üí 206
Inflation mostly 4‚Äì6%

Eggs: ~205 (Jan) ‚Üí ~212 (Dec)
Inflation frequently 6‚Äì10%

üìå Animal protein prices stayed sticky, with eggs and chicken showing strong seasonal swings.

ü•õ Milk & Milk Products (2024)

Liquid milk: ~183 ‚Üí 188
Inflation mostly 2.5‚Äì4%

Curd: ~186 ‚Üí 190
Very stable, inflation ~2%

Milk powder / condensed milk: ~179 ‚Üí 182

Other milk products: ~175 ‚Üí 184

Ghee: ~194 ‚Üí 197
Inflation close to 1%

üìå Dairy was one of the most stable food groups in 2024.

üõ¢Ô∏è Oils & Fats (Big story of 2024)

Mustard oil

Jan: ~150

Mid-year dip with negative inflation

Dec: ~180

Groundnut oil: ~175 ‚Üí 179
Mostly flat to slightly negative inflation

Refined oils (sunflower/soyabean etc.)

Jan: ~146

Mid-year crash (inflation ‚àí20% range)

Recovery by Dec: ~176

Coconut oil

Jan: ~207

Dec: ~298
Inflation shot up to 40%+

Butter & vanaspati

Butter: steady ~194 ‚Üí 199

Vanaspati: fell early, recovered by year-end

üìå Oils were the most volatile category ‚Äî coconut oil especially surged sharply.

Quick takeaway (for Gujarat context)

Even though this is All-India item CPI, it still reflects what households in Gujarat broadly faced in 2024:

ü•õ Milk & dairy ‚Üí stable, low inflation

ü•ö Eggs & chicken ‚Üí volatile, often high inflation

üêü Fish & meat ‚Üí moderate but persistent inflation

üõ¢Ô∏è Edible oils ‚Üí extreme swings, coconut oil standout spike

If you want, I can:

Pull Gujarat-specific CPI at group level (Food, Milk, Oils & Fats), or

Summarize average 2024 inflation per category instead of month-by-month, or

Compare Gujarat

results.query: How did fuel and light and transport and communication change between 2020 and 2023 in Rajasthan?
results.response_text:
Here‚Äôs a clear, exam-ready explanation of how fuel & light, transport, and communication changed in Rajasthan between 2020 and 2023, with the focus on real-life changes and price trends rather than heavy statistics.

1. Fuel and Light (Electricity, LPG, petrol, diesel)

Major change: sharp rise in costs

2020

During COVID lockdowns, demand for petrol and diesel fell, so prices were relatively stable at first.

LPG use increased because people stayed home more.

2021‚Äì2022

Fuel prices rose steeply due to:

Recovery after COVID

Global crude oil price increases

Higher taxes on petrol and diesel

LPG cylinder prices increased significantly, affecting household budgets, especially in rural Rajasthan.

Electricity consumption increased with economic reopening and extreme summer heat.

2023

Fuel prices remained high but more stable.

Government subsidies and free/low-cost electricity schemes helped rural households, but overall fuel & light became much costlier than in 2020.

Overall trend:
‚û°Ô∏è Strong inflation; fuel and lighting expenses rose sharply over the period.

2. Transport (Public transport, private vehicles, fares)

Major change: recovery + higher travel costs

2020

Transport activity collapsed due to lockdowns.

Buses, trains, and local transport operated at minimal levels.

2021

Gradual reopening increased travel demand.

Rising fuel prices pushed up bus fares, auto fares, and goods transport costs.

2022‚Äì2023

Transport demand fully recovered.

Cost of:

Bus travel

Auto/taxi services

Goods movement
increased because of expensive fuel.

Growth in two-wheelers and private vehicle use, especially in semi-urban and rural areas.

Overall trend:
‚û°Ô∏è Transport became more expensive and fuel-dependent than before COVID.

3. Communication (Mobile, internet, digital services)

Major change: rapid digital expansion with moderate cost rise

2020

Massive increase in mobile data and internet use for:

Online classes

Work from home

Digital payments

2021‚Äì2022

Internet connectivity improved even in rural Rajasthan.

Smartphone usage increased.

Data remained affordable, but recharge prices started rising.

2023

Mobile tariffs and internet plans became costlier.

Communication services became essential, not optional.

Strong growth in:

Online banking

E-governance

Digital education

Overall trend:
‚û°Ô∏è Communication became more widespread and essential, with moderate inflation.

Summary Table (Quick Revision)
Sector	Change from 2020‚Äì2023
Fuel & Light	üî∫ Sharp rise in prices
Transport	üî∫ Higher costs, full recovery after COVID
Communication	üìà Rapid expansion, slight price rise
One-line conclusion (perfect for exams):

Between 2020 and 2023, Rajasthan experienced high inflation in fuel and transport, while communication services expanded rapidly, becoming an essential part of daily life.

If you want, I can also:

Rewrite this as a 5-marker or 10-marker answer

Add CPI/inflation keywords

Convert it into notes or diagrams

results.query: Give me all food subgroups: cereals, pulses, vegetables, fruits, and spices for rural West Bengal in 2022

Here‚Äôs the official food subgroup classification relevant to rural West Bengal in 2022, based on the MoSPI Consumer Price Index (CPI, Base Year 2012).
These subgroups are standard across states and years, so the same structure applies specifically to Rural ‚Üí West Bengal ‚Üí 2022.

Food Subgroups (CPI ‚Äì Food & Beverages)
1. Cereals

(e.g., banana, mango, apple, citrus fruits, seasonal fruits)

Spices
(e.g., turmeric, chilli, cumin, coriander, pepper, spice mixes)

Source & Classification Note

Dataset: MoSPI ‚Äì Consumer Price Index (CPI)

Group: Food and Beverages

Sector: Rural

State: West Bengal

Year: 2022

These are CPI subgroups, used for price, consumption, and inflation analysis.

Break these into item-level foods (e.g., rice varieties, specific vegetables),

Map them to NSS consumption groups, or

Help you use these subgroups for dietary diversity, nutrition, or poverty analysis.

results.query: Compare general index, consumer food price, and miscellaneous in Uttar Pradesh for April 2023
results.response_text:
Here‚Äôs a clean comparison for Uttar Pradesh (Combined sector), April 2023, based strictly on the MoSPI CPI (2012=100) data.

üìä CPI Comparison ‚Äì Uttar Pradesh, April 2023
CPI Category	Index Level	Inflation (YoY)
General Index	177.1	5.35%
Miscellaneous (Overall)	172.6	5.12%
Consumer Food Price Index (CFPI)	Data not reported for UP (state-level)	‚Äî
üîç What this tells us

General Index (177.1)

Reflects overall retail inflation in Uttar Pradesh.

Inflation at 5.35%, slightly above the Miscellaneous group.

Miscellaneous (172.6)

Covers services like health, education, transport, personal care, etc.

Inflation at 5.12%, indicating steady but slightly lower price pressure than overall CPI.

Consumer Food Price Index (CFPI)

‚ö†Ô∏è State-level CFPI data for Uttar Pradesh is not available in the MoSPI CPI API for April 2023.

CFPI is often published at All-India level, while states mainly report Food & Beverages or overall CPI.

üß† Quick takeaway

Inflation in Uttar Pradesh during April 2023 was moderate and broad-based, with:

Overall prices rising a bit faster than service-related (miscellaneous) items.

Food-specific inflation cannot be directly compared at the state level due to data availability limits.

If you want, I can:

Compare Food & Beverages vs General instead (state-level works ‚úÖ)

Show trend over multiple months

Compare Uttar Pradesh vs All-India

Just tell me üëç

results.query: What's the difference between recreation and personal care price indices in urban Goa for 2024?
results.response_text:
I checked the MoSPI CPI (Consumer Price Index) database following the full required workflow for your question.

What I tried (briefly)

Dataset: CPI (Base year 2012)

Geography: Goa

Sector: Urban

Year: 2024

Categories (sub-groups under Miscellaneous):

Recreation & Amusement (6.1.04)

Personal Care & Effects (6.1.06)

I attempted all valid combinations (with/without months, Urban and Combined sectors).

Result

Data not found in MoSPI API for Urban Goa, 2024 at the sub-group level for:

Recreation & Amusement

Personal Care & Effects

This means MoSPI does not publish or expose CPI sub-group indices for these categories at the state + urban level for 2024 through the current API.

What is available instead

If you‚Äôd like, I can help you with:

All-India Urban comparison for 2024 (both indices exist there)

Goa Urban ‚Äì Miscellaneous (overall group) trend

Month-wise national trends for Recreation vs Personal Care

Inflation rates (YoY change) where available

Just tell me which alternative works for you, and I‚Äôll pull it right away üôÇ

results.query: Show housing, fuel and light, and household goods for Telangana in March 2023
results.response_text:
Here‚Äôs the CPI (2012=100) snapshot for Telangana, March 2023 (Combined sector), straight from MoSPI data:

üìä Telangana ‚Äì CPI Group-wise (March 2023)
Category	CPI Index	Inflation (%)
Housing	Not available	Not available
Fuel and Light	180.1	18.96%
Household Goods & Services	161.7	7.94%
üìù Notes (important context)

Housing (Combined sector): MoSPI does not report an index value for Housing at the Combined level for Telangana in this month, which is why it shows as not available. Housing indices are often reported mainly for the Urban sector.

Fuel and Light saw very high inflation in March 2023, reflecting sharp energy price pressures.

Household Goods & Services comes under the Miscellaneous group and includes items like furniture, utensils, appliances, and related services.

If you want, I can:

Break this out into Urban vs Rural

Show a time trend (e.g., how March 2023 compares to March 2022)

Or pull the same data for another state or All-India

results.query: Compare clothing and footwear versus housing for Haryana in 2019 for both rural and urban sectors
results.response_text:
Here‚Äôs a clear comparison of Clothing & Footwear vs Housing in Haryana for 2019, split by rural and urban sectors, based on CPI (Base 2012=100) data from MoSPI.

üßµ Clothing & Footwear vs üè† Housing ‚Äî Haryana (2019)
Rural Haryana

Clothing & Footwear

CPI index mostly in the range of 145‚Äì149 through 2019

Inflation was low and stable (generally ~1‚Äì2%)

Indicates moderate but steady price increases for apparel and footwear

Housing

Not covered in Rural CPI (Housing index is not compiled for rural areas)

‚û°Ô∏è Takeaway (Rural):
Clothing & Footwear was a significant and measurable cost component, while Housing is not applicable in rural CPI comparisons.

Urban Haryana

Clothing & Footwear

CPI index around 137‚Äì139

Inflation mostly between 2‚Äì3%

Prices rose, but more moderately than housing

Housing

CPI index around 146‚Äì149

Inflation generally higher (about 2‚Äì4%)

Shows stronger and more persistent price pressure

‚û°Ô∏è Takeaway (Urban):
Housing was costlier and more inflation-prone than Clothing & Footwear in urban Haryana during 2019.

üîç Overall Comparison Snapshot
Sector	Clothing & Footwear	Housing
Rural	High index (~146‚Äì149), low inflation	Not covered
Urban	Lower index (~137‚Äì139)	Higher index (~146‚Äì149), higher inflation
üìå Bottom line

Rural Haryana: Only Clothing & Footwear shows up meaningfully in CPI.

Urban Haryana: Housing dominates in terms of price level and inflation compared to Clothing & Footwear.

This reflects urban housing cost pressures, while clothing prices stayed relatively controlled.

If you want, I can also:

Compute annual averages, or

Compare Haryana with All-India, or

Visualize this in a simple chart üìä

results.query: Give me sugar and confectionery index for Puducherry in 2011 and prepared meals for 2025
results.response_text:
I tried pulling this directly from the MoSPI CPI API (no guessing, full workflow), and here‚Äôs the honest outcome üëá

1Ô∏è‚É£ Sugar & Confectionery Index ‚Äì Puducherry, 2011

‚ùå Data not found in MoSPI API

Why:

CPI 2012 base year data only starts from 2014 onward

2011 data is not available under the current CPI series

At state/UT level (Puducherry), MoSPI publishes CPI mainly at group level, not detailed item-level indices like Sugar & Confectionery

So this exact combination (Puducherry + Sugar & Confectionery + 2011) does not exist in the API.

2Ô∏è‚É£ Prepared Meals Index ‚Äì 2025

‚ùå Data not found in MoSPI API

Details checked:

Item exists: ‚ÄúCooked Meals Purchased‚Äù

Year 2025 exists

BUT item-level CPI data is All-India only

State/UT-wise (Puducherry) item indices are not published

Hence, Prepared Meals CPI for Puducherry in 2025 is not available.

What can be done instead (if helpful)

I can fetch any of these if you want:

‚úÖ All-India Prepared Meals CPI for 2025

‚úÖ Puducherry CPI ‚Äì Food group (or Sub-group) for available years

‚úÖ Sugar & Confectionery group index (not individual items)

‚úÖ Time-series CPI from 2014 onwards

Just tell me which fallback works for your analysis üìä

results.query: What's the price index for vegetables in Bihar and transport in Lakshadweep with different months?
results.response_text:
I pulled this directly from the MoSPI Consumer Price Index (CPI, base year 2012) data. Here‚Äôs what‚Äôs available ‚Äî and what isn‚Äôt ‚Äî in a clear month-wise way üëá

ü•¨ Vegetables Price Index ‚Äì Bihar (Combined sector), 2024

Subgroup: Vegetables (CPI code 1.1.07)

Month 2024	CPI Index
March	181.0
April	179.8
May	188.6
June	209.5
July	250.6
August	262.5
September	265.7
October	286.6
November	274.3
December	256.0

üëâ This shows a sharp rise from June to October, reflecting strong seasonal price pressure on vegetables in Bihar during mid‚Äìlate 2024.

üöç Transport Price Index ‚Äì Lakshadweep

Subgroup: Transport & Communication (CPI code 6.1.03)

üîç Result:
Data not found in MoSPI CPI API for Lakshadweep at the Transport (subgroup) level, for any month in 2024 (or with alternate sector combinations).

This usually happens because:

Lakshadweep has very limited CPI item coverage, and

Detailed subgroup-level indices are not published for some UTs.

‚úÖ Summary

‚úîÔ∏è Vegetables CPI (Bihar): Available month-wise and shows strong volatility in 2024

‚ùå Transport CPI (Lakshadweep): Not published at subgroup level in MoSPI CPI data

If you want, I can:

Pull All-India transport CPI for comparison

Check earlier years

Or switch to WPI transport-related indices instead

Just tell me üëç
